Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tectonic Links, Magma Fluxes, and Single Mineral Geochemistry in Plutonic Systems From 5-30 km Depth, Cascades Core, Washington
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Tectonic links, magma fluxes, and single mineral geochemistry in plutonic systems from 5-30 km depth, Cascades core, Washington

Intellectual Merit. Continental magmatic arcs are the site of massive additions of mantle derived magmas which serve to drive melting, thickening, and reorganization of the crust. Much of what we know about Cretaceous and older continental magmatic arcs results from studies of the physics and chemistry of plutonic rocks, and the derivative data strongly influence models of crustal growth and evolution. In contrast to modern arcs where single eruptive units may be analyzed, plutons record a much richer, albeit complex, history and represent a much greater percentage of the total magmatic flux than volcanic rocks alone. Critical questions concern how and at what rate intermediate composition magmas move through the crustal column, and how the crust accommodates these potentially large fluxes? Key to answering these questions is to understand how large masses of crystallized magmas or plutons and batholiths are constructed. To address these questions, collaborative research is proposed to better understand sub-arc magmatic plumbing systems. This project focuses on the roots of a continental magmatic arc in the North Cascades that comprises three well-exposed intrusive bodies emplaced at different depths in the crust. Integrated field mapping, structural analysis, mineral geochemistry, high-precision geochronology and coupled isotopic studies will be employed to [1] determine the degree to which plutons represent single magma batches or complex mixtures of partially crystallized magmas of different origins, [2] estimate magma flux rates and timescales for melt generation, transport, and eruption of intermediate composition magmas, and [3] evaluate potential linkages between regional tectonic strain and magma formation. This multidisciplinary collaborative research is expected to contribute significantly to understanding of magma plumbing systems and the formation of plutons in continental magmatic arcs.

Broader Impacts. This research will support Ph.D. students at MIT and USC, and at least 2 M.S. students at SJSU, and multiple undergraduate student assistants at all 4 institutions. Bpth SJSU PIs have supervised 2 B.S. research projects supported by their most recent grants, and Paterson teaches a formal research class at USC that has involved >20 undergraduates in NSF-supported research. Graduate students from SJSU and USC will visit Kent's lab at OSU to conduct their own analyses, and the MIT graduate student will visit SJSU and assist in SHRIMP analyses. Four M.S. students at SJSU have gone to MIT to carry out U-Pb dating under the tutelage of PI Bowring and his students, and this type of interaction is expected to continue. All of the PIs routinely incorporate their research in class lectures and use research samples in lab courses. Most importantly, The PI's are demonstrating to a large cross section of new students the power of strongly interdisciplinary and collaborative work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Critical questions for magmatic arc systems are how and at what rate magmas move through the crust, and how does the crust accommodate these potentially large fluxes? Key to answering these questions is to understand how large masses of crystallized magmas (plutons and batholiths) are constructed. To evaluate these questions, we conducted a detailed integrated study of one of the few well-exposed, deeply exhumed continental magmatic arcs, the North Cascades of the NW North America, where it is possible to examine 90 million year old magmatic plumbing systems from the lower to upper crust, and potentially to associated volcanoes. Focus was placed on three coeval plutons that crystallized at vastly different depths (5-30 km) in the crust. Field mapping, structural analysis, detailed mineral geochemistry, and high-precision geochronology and coupled isotopic studies were integrated to determine the degree to which plutons represent a few large batches of magma or complex mixtures of partially crystallized magmas of different chemistries and ages.

Work on the deep (~25-30 km paleodepth) Tenpeak pluton concentrated on a zone of sheets of variable chemical composition. Mapping led to the construction of a 350-m-thick “stratigraphic section” in which most sheets range from ~10 cm - 10 m in thickness and increase in thickness upward. An implication of the field and laboratory data from the pluton is that at least some thick, highly sheeted zones within deep-crustal intrusions were rapidly constructed and preserve evidence for dynamic interaction at the emplacement level, but individual injections remain easily recognizable.

In the mid-crustal (20-25 km paleodepth) Seven Fingered Jack pluton, field, microscopic, and geochemical data imply that it was also incrementally constructed mainly by steep, <1 m to 500 m wide sheets and irregularly shaped bodies. These sheets amalgamated into km-scale bodies with subtle internal contacts.

Field research in the mid- to shallow-crustal (<5 to 10 km paleodepth) Black Peak batholith indicates it has a steep wall that rolls over into a flat roof. Blocks of host rock (low-grade metamorphic rocks) occur near the wall and numerous, 1 m-10s of m-thick dikes and irregularly shaped bodies intrude the pluton roof. These observations imply at least modest uplift of the pluton roof and stoping (breaking off) of the host rock. This brittle style of emplacement contrasts with the more ductile style of the deeper plutons.

The three plutons were geochemically analyzed by multiple techniques. Rare Earth Element patterns, combined with high levels of Al2O3, indicate that magmas were generated by partial melting of a crustal source shallower than the depth of garnet stability (~40 km). These observations contrast with those of the deep-crustal Tenpeak pluton and shallow Black Peak batholith, both of which have abundant evidence for a garnet source. The observation that the intrusion depth does not correlate with whole rock geochemistry suggests that the melt source exerts a fundamental control on the geochemistry of the magmas. Mid- to shallow crustal modification by transfer of minerals, mixing of magmas, and removal of crystals (fractionation) does not erase this fundamental geochemical aspect of the magmas.

Oxygen isotope analysis of zircons from the three intrusions shows that the magmas from which zircons crystalized involved local crustal sources, as δ18O values are nearly all higher than the nominal mantle value. Local igneous arc crust was the primary source, but the shallow Black Peak and deep Tenpeak pluton also assimilated metasedimentary and/or metavolcanic host rocks.
